parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post promotes a radio show with guests discussing unspecified topics.  There is no mention of any parliamentary candidate or party.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, aiming to reach a wide audience to promote a radio show. The reach estimate is 100K-500K.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>False. The objective of the post is to promote a radio show, not to influence the vote for any particular candidate in the parliamentary elections. The content of the radio show itself is unknown, but the advertisement doesn't contain any electoral messaging.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>True. Promoting a radio show, especially one with guests discussing potentially political topics, can be considered a form of journalistic activity, aiming to inform the public.  The post itself is not directly influencing the vote.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>Not applicable. The post doesn't express a personal opinion.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1138349474474550</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post promotes a radio show ("DIALOGUL DE VINERI") on Bistrita FM.  While the topics discussed in the show might indirectly touch upon political issues, the advertisement itself does not contain any electoral propaganda. It doesn't mention any parliamentary candidates, parties, or explicitly advocate for or against any political position related to the parliamentary elections. The advertisement's purpose is solely to promote the radio show, and the paid nature of the post on a public platform indicates an attempt to reach a wide audience, but not to influence the vote.  The fact that the post falls under the "POLITICAL" category in Facebook's ad library doesn't automatically qualify it as electoral propaganda; it simply reflects the general political nature of the radio station's programming.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>Bistrita FM</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
